abstract.p: Michael Wines comments on bars in Moscow and his favorite, Justo on Tolmachevsky Pereulok; drawing (The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of 2-part section)

block.p: The Russian word for ''bar'' is ''bar.'' That should suggest how foreign the concept initially was. Choosing Moscow's best bar is like choosing Russia's best 10-year-old physicist. They're there. Just give them time to grow up.

That said, Moscow has some good bars. There's the elegant bar at the Metropole, perhaps the city's swankiest hotel, hard against the Kremlin, and the Kitaisky Lyotchik, or Chinese Pilot, a relaxed, neighborhood kind of place where one can catch live music at night and break-fast in the morning. And there's the bar at the Zolotoe Koltso, a hotel opposite the soaring Stalinesque foreign ministry headquarters, where the view from 22 stories makes up for the lack of decor.

That said, Moscow has some good bars. There's the elegant bar at the Metropole, perhaps the city's swankiest hotel, hard against the Kremlin, and the Kitaisky Lyotchik, or Chinese Pilot, a relaxed, neighborhood kind of place where one can catch live music at night and break-fast in the morning. And there's the bar at the Zolotoe Koltso, a hotel opposite the soaring Stalinesque foreign ministry headquarters, where the view from 22 stories makes up for the lack of decor.
The watering hole of the moment, however, is Justo, not far across the Moscow River from the Kremlin on Tolmachevsky Pereulok, one of the city's more European streets.

A private club until last November, Justo is now open to anyone, as long as he or she is sufficiently hip: admittance requires ringing a doorbell and passing the bouncer's scrutiny. ''You have to ring the bell to get into the finest homes,'' says Ruslan Tarkinsky, the 32-year-old, very hip, buzz-cut manager.
If it sounds contrived, it is. But the bar itself turns out to be a friendly sort of place in which suits and the black-turtleneck crowd coexist with a minimum of discomfort.

Within the gate is a courtyard nightclub, beneath a soaring khaki-colored canopy. Inside, down the stairs, is an intimate saloon-cum-disco-cum-restaurant, with a semicircular chrome bar as a hub for distinctive smaller rooms, populated with comfortable sofas and natural wood tables. The decor is stark gray: black-and-white photos projected on gray concrete walls and gray sheets of linen, and a screen for silent movies (black-and-white, of course). One nice touch of color: the glass-walled coatroom features glowing fluorescent coat checks.

The house merlot is $6 a glass, and the beers -- Kirin and Sapporo in bottles, Heineken and Grolsch on tap -- are cheaper than in New York. The liquor list is not long, but the major brands are there, in both Russian and charmingly misspelled English.
Moscow's best bar? Justo is certainly a contender. But for coolness, nobody else is close.
